packet.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a container made of paper, plastic, or cardboard that something is sold in
packet.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a small flat paper or plastic container that a liquid or powder is sold in
packet.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a small flat package that is sent by post or delivered to someone
packet.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Paul tore open the packet as soon as it arrived.
packet.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a quantity of information that is sent as a single unit from one computer to another on a network or on the Internet
packet.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a small container, usually made of paper, with a set of things in it
packet.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: United Biscuits produces 5 billion packets a year.
Supermarkets withdrew thousands of packets of chocolates after discovering a production error.
Under a direct-marketing promotion, Quaker Oats sent out packets of coupons to 18 million homes.
packet.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a small plastic or paper package containing a product in liquid or paper form
packet.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a set of related things or services which are offered or sold together
packet.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: He advised the firm to buy a packet of Jacobs Suchard shares to facilitate the takeover.
We are putting together a packet of services from various parts of the bank.
packet.translation[1].definitions[3].def: a unit of data that is sent over a computer network such as the Internet. Packets that belong to the same file can travel over different routes and be joined together again when they arrive
packet.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to cost a lot of money
packet.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: It can cost a packet to use a mobile abroad.
packet.translation[1].definitions[5].def: a set of documents kept together between the same covers
